item.title: Genshin Impact Officially Reveals Nefer for Version 6.1
item.description:
Genshin Impact has officially revealed Nefer, the boss of the Curatorium of Secrets, as a 5-Star Dendro Catalyst coming in Version 6.1. With Version 6.0 underway, Genshin Impact has opened the doors of Nod-Krai to the Traveler. Located on the southern borders of Snezhnaya, individuals and factions from all over Teyvat gather in Nod-Krai. Version 6.0 introduced players to a vibrant cast, but only added three to the list of playable characters: Lauma, Flins, and Aino.

Flins and Aino are due to debut in the second half of Version 6.0, but Lauma is currently available on the Event Banners. She is a 5-Star Dendro Catalyst who buffs Lunar-Bloom and Dendro reactions. While Lauma is a versatile support character in Genshin Impact , players should also consider her synergy with the upcoming Nefer.

Genshin Impact: Nefer

  • Rarity : 5-Star
  • Gender : Female
  • Element : Dendro
  • Weapon : Catalyst
  • Constellation : Ludus Latrunculorum

Nefer will be the sole character of Version 6.1, officially announced by Genshin Impact across social media. She will be a Lunar-Bloom hypercarry, allowing Lauma to use the other half of her support kit. Much like Wriothesley, Nefer in Genshin Impact will be a Catalyst who fights at melee range, but her gameplay style is primarily compared to Skirk. She generates resources by triggering Lunar-Bloom reactions, and spends them via Charged Attacks enhanced by her Elemental Skill.

An important thing to keep in mind is Nefer's over-reliance on Lauma in Genshin Impact . Much like Escoffier for Skirk, there is a huge difference in power between a Nefer team without a Lauma and a Nefer team with Lauma. As such, it is important for Genshin Impact players to obtain both characters if they intend to build a premium team for Nefer. This trend has been critiqued since the emergence of Citlali and Mavuika, but it would seem that the developers are still keen to lean into it.

Thankfully, Version 6.0 is abundant in Primogems, and even free-to-play accounts will be able to obtain over a hundred Intertwined Wishes. Assuming players saved up on their Primogems in Genshin Impact before Nod-Krai, they should be able to guarantee both 5-Star characters by the start of November. However, given that Columbina is expected to join the playable cast in Version 6.3, players should keep an eye out for how the Moon Maiden would fit a premium Nefer team. Whereas Nefer and Lauma form a powerful core, the other two slots have yet to crystallize â€“ with Yelan, Xinqiu, Aino, Nahida, Baizhu, and Zhongli all viable options. Version 6.1 is set to launch on October 22, 2025.

item.title: Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream Narrows Down Release Date
item.description:
Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream has narrowed down its release window, targeting a Spring 2026 release. The new release window came alongside a look at Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream 's gameplay, giving players a better idea of what to expect.

Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream marks the third entry to the series, but the first game didn't release outside of Japan, so this is only the second game to arrive in the west. The last entry arrived on the Nintendo 3DS 12 years ago, so Tomodachi Life fans have been waiting for a follow-up for a long time. Though the game was previously revealed by Nintendo, this new look has given a better idea of what the game will look like and what new features are being added to the latest entry.

Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream Gives Look at Gameplay

During the September Nintendo Direct, Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream revealed a short trailer that announced that the game has narrowed its release window from all of 2026 to Spring 2026. The game will launch on the Nintendo Switch, and will be backward-compatible on the Switch 2. Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream will let players populate their new island with Miis that they can customize however they like. Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream detailed the Mii character builder, which lets players customize their Miis quite a bit, including changing their ears, a detail Miis previously lacked. Players can also expect to choose Miis' voices, which lets players choose from Speed, Pitch, Depth, Delivery, and Tone, to their personality, with sliders for Movement, Speech, Energy, Thinking, and Overall.

Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream showed off a bit of how players will be able to control and direct their Miis. One example showed feeding a hungry Mii, and then revealed a screen showing their happiness level, hunger, loves, likes, and dislikes. Further, the next game appears to be tackling an issue some gamers had with the prior entry, allowing players to intervene and cause two Miis to interact directly, rather than hoping that the Miis interact on their own. Some additional glimpses teased things like Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream 's mini-games, the island environments, and silly ways of interacting with Miis.

With several games still arriving for Switch and Switch 2 in 2025, it may be a bit before Nintendo sheds more light on this coming title. Thankfully, though, players now know that their wait for the game won't extend beyond Spring 2026, so they don't have too much longer to get their hands on Tomodachi Life: Living the Dream .

item.title: Hades 2â€™s September 25 Launch is a Boon and a Curse
item.description:
Hades 2 , pedestaled by my adoration for its god-like roguelike predecessor, is a game that Iâ€™ve looked forward to since it was announced that Supergiant was developing its first-ever sequel. Iâ€™ve only ever played two games in early accessâ€” No Rest for the Wicked and Hades 2 â€”and, while I respect and understand why some developers choose to release a game in early access for extensive periods before their full, 1.0 release, I would personally prefer to play a game when the final product is ready. This way, I can invest in them wholly, with the reassurance that I wonâ€™t eventually reach a cliffside where content has abruptly ceased and wonâ€™t be available until their 1.0 release. Thankfully, Hades 2 â€™s 1.0 release date has finally been revealed.

Early access periods are terrific opportunities to support developers, although their indefinite timelines, including milestones and goals they havenâ€™t yet met, guarantee that Iâ€™ll inevitably transition to other gamesâ€™ releases in the meantime. That said, the time between when I retired my early access playthrough of Hades 2 and today has created a greater yearning for the full release. Sadly, in a cruel twist of fate, Hades 2 is scheduled to be released on September 25, which lands it squarely on the same day as Silent Hill f , the only game that couldâ€™ve possibly eclipsed it in terms of my enthusiasm and suspense now that Hollow Knight: Silksong has been released.

Hades 2 1.0 is Finally Nigh, But Itâ€™s Contending With a Psychological Horror Titan

If it wasnâ€™t for Silent Hill f , Hades 2 would have no competition at all in my barren slate of anticipated game releases for the rest of the year. For instance, Iâ€™m uncertain if Iâ€™ll cave and play Ghost of Yotei at the beginning of October; indie sensation Hollow Knight: Silksong was released earlier this month and, engrossed in prolonging it and exploring at a snailâ€™s pace, Iâ€™ll likely be finished it in the next couple of weeks; and no other release in the next few months piques my interest besides Little Nightmares 3 and Metroid 4: Beyond , while Iâ€™m still trying to carve out time to play Cronos: The New Dawn .

Had Hades 2 been launching its 1.0 version in October, November, or December, Iâ€™d feel free to devote all my time to it. But, because it launches literally on the same day as one of my most anticipated games of the year, Iâ€™m afraid Iâ€™ll be making a priority of Silent Hill f â€™s release date instead.

Iâ€™ll technically be playing two days early, on September 22, via Silent Hill f â€™s Digital Deluxe edition bonus, but I presume it will take me longer than a few days to beat it, anyhow.

Not only does f look like itâ€™s fashioned with all the right garments to make a fantastic Silent Hill game, but its novelty and boldness in a franchise thatâ€™s otherwise been left without a meaningful pulse before Blooberâ€™s Silent Hill 2 remake is enough to instill me with hope for how the series may take shape hereafter. The little Iâ€™ve played of Hades 2 in early access back when it was released last year was spectacular, but it isnâ€™t necessarily shattering the earth around its IP in the same way that f seems to be for Silent Hill . As you can probably surmise, Hollow Knight: Silksong , Silent Hill f , and Hades 2 all releasing in the same month have made September 2025 fairly special for me.

Has Hades 2â€™s Hype Dwindled in Early Access?

The short answer is: no. Anyone whoâ€™s been excited for Hades â€™ roguelike sequel, even if they have chosen not to stay up to date with it for the remainder of its early access period or will have another game theyâ€™re awaiting by the end of September, is likely only reinvigorated by the fact that it is launching later this month, unless they somehow grew weary of it already while playing it for the past 16 monthsâ€”a couple of months shy of a year and a half since May 5, 2024.

Hades 2 is scheduled to be released on September 25, which lands it squarely on the same day as Silent Hill f , the only game that couldâ€™ve possibly eclipsed it in terms of my enthusiasm and suspense now that Hollow Knight: Silksong has been released.

This period and how lengthy it may seem on paperâ€”whether thatâ€™s due to a gnawing eagerness to see its full launch and how the story unfolds, the anticipation of those who are uninitiated with early access periods and had only hopped into Hades during its full launch, or some extraneous factorâ€”wonâ€™t be unfamiliar to anyone who was around for Hades â€™ early access. Indeed, Hades entered early access on December 6, 2018, as an Epic Games Store exclusive, and did not launch with 1.0 on Nintendo Switch and PC until September 17, 2020.

So, by comparison, the Hades community is fortunate enough to be receiving the sequelâ€™s 1.0 less than two years from when it first entered early access, especially when the content of Hades 2 â€™s early access has already eclipsed that of the entire first game. Early access is obviously essential to Supergiantâ€™s creative and development process, and it wonâ€™t be surprising if this is the formula it adheres to for the foreseeable future, regardless of whether its next game after Hades 2 is its second-ever sequel or a brand-new IP.

Baldurâ€™s Gate 3 â€™s early access went on for almost three years, and such leniency may well be the norm for games to reach their full potential and release with a 1.0 that is as complete and polished as possible.

Tragically, I decided 12-or-so hours into my Hades 2 early access playthrough that I would cease progress and wait however long it took to reinstall the game when it fully launched. Now, with a heavy heart, Iâ€™ll be shelving it in my backlog until at least October because Silent Hill f is being released on the same day. I canâ€™t complain, though; playing Hollow Knight: Silksong , Silent Hill f , and Hades 2 back-to-back is going to be a treat that wonâ€™t be taken for granted.

item.title: How Borderlands 4 Reviews Compare to Other Games in the Franchise
item.description:
The general sentiment towards Borderlands 4 wasn't all that positive before its release. While the trailers and gameplay previews that Gearbox Software released for the game didn't make a particularly bad impression on fans, one of the comments made by the company's CEO, Randy Pitchford, didn't exactly do it any favors. A few months ago, Borderlands 4 became embroiled in controversy after Pitchford stated on Twitter that "real fans" would buy the game no matter what, even if it cost $80.

Later on, it was revealed that the base version of Borderlands 4 would have a $70 price tag instead of an $80 one, but some fans were still disappointed with the high prices of its Deluxe and Super Deluxe editions.

Pricing concerns aside, many gamers were also skeptical of Borderlands 4 due to the quality of the last few entries in the franchise. None of the Borderlands games that Gearbox released were terrible, per se, but Borderlands 3 and Tiny Tina's Wonderlands , in particular, received pretty mixed reviews. Many assumed that Borderlands 4 would not be able to reach the heights of the first two Borderlands games, but recent reviews for the title have been largely positive, despite some notable issues.

Borderlands 4 is One of the Highest-Rated Games in the Series Yet

On OpenCritic, Borderlands 4 has received a Top Critic Average of 85/100 and a critic approval rating of 97%. Ratings for the game on Metacritic are similarly positive, with its PC version garnering a generally favorable score of 84/100. Many of the critics who reviewed Borderlands 4 consider it a return to form for the series, an d some have even gone so far as to call it one of the best Borderlands games yet. The game's improved gunplay, sense of humor, and visuals have all received widespread praise from critics, but its open world elements, limited enemy variety, and significant performance issues on PC have been criticized by some.

Despite its positive critical reception, the user rating for Borderlands 4 on Steam is currently mixed, largely due to the technical issues that the game's PC port suffers from.

Critic Scores for Borderlands 4 Are Just as Good as Borderlands 1, But Not On Par With Borderlands 2

This may be surprising to some fans, but Borderlands 4 is technically the second-highest-rated mainline installment in the franchise on both OpenCritic and Metacritic. At the time of writing this article, Borderlands 2 is the only mainline game in the series whose critic score hasn't been surpassed.

That said, o n Metacritic specifically , Borderlands 4 is currently tied with the original Borderlands , as that title received an 84/100 score on Xbox 360 back in the day. While the other Borderlands entries have received similarly positive review scores, they're still somewhat behind Borderlands 2 , Borderlands 4 , and the first Borderlands in terms of critical acclaim.

Borderlands 2: Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep also has a higher score than Borderlands 4 on Metacritic, but it is technically a DLC, and not a full game.

Borderlands 4 Has Received Better Reviews than Borderlands 3 and Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel was the first full-fledged Borderlands game to be released after Borderlan ds 2 , and it garnered a somewhat more mixed reception compared t o its predecessors. The title received a decent 75/100 score on Metacritic and a 74/100 Top Critic Average on OpenCritic. Borderlands 3 , meanw hile, got an 81/100 rating on both OpenCritic and Metacritic, and it was criticized by fans for its childish humor and lack of innovation.

item.title: Best PS1 Games That Aged Like Milk
item.description:
There were a lot of important franchises that leveled up during the PS1 era, including Final Fantasy and Metal Gear . Then some franchises began on the PS1, like Crash Bandicoot, Resident Evil, Syphon Filter , and more. It was an important system, no one can deny that, with a lot of great titles that are still fun to play today, natively on an old PS1 or through ports on consoles like the Switch.

Then there are games that, while important in the PS1's library, are not as fun to play today. The voice acting, controls, graphics, and more may be a bit too much to handle for modern gamers without nostalgia glasses. They're not bad, but they just belong in a different time and place. Plus, in most cases, there are better modern versions or sequels that one-upped these games.

Ape Escape is one of the more forgotten platformer series exclusive to PlayStation consoles. It was forward-thinking at the time as it used analog sticks to control and take actions in the game. This original game can be played via emulation on a PS5, but even a modern controller canâ€™t help it much, as the controls are a bit awkward, and the PSP version, also on PS5, is slightly more accessible. Further sequels solidified the controls more, making it less awkward to move and switch between tools to capture the various escaped apes.

Crash Bandicoot is a more beloved platformer series that started on the PS1, but a lot of people tend to forget about this first game. Thatâ€™s because the controls werenâ€™t perfect back then, and they are even less tactile now. This made some of the levels incredibly hard, plus there wasnâ€™t much personality from the gameâ€™s villains or heroes. Crash Bandicoot 2: Cortex Strikes Back is where Naughty Dog figured out the right balance between difficulty, storytelling, and interesting level design, which makes going back to this first game a bit pointless.

The graphics made it seem even more dated as it used sprites not that much better than a SNES game, which wasnâ€™t a bad thing necessarily.

There is charm to the sprites, but what wasnâ€™t charming was the slow-paced narrative and the game not telling players where to go, necessarily. It was fun on the PS1 for VERY patient players, but anyone who wants to experience this admittedly great Dragon Quest entry should check out the 3DS version, which added a lot of quality-of-life features.

Koei Tecmo just put out a trailer to celebrate 25 years of Dynasty Warriors , going back as far as Dynasty Warriors 2 . That should say something about how they feel regarding the actual first game, Dynasty Warriors , which was a PS1 exclusive fighting game. Next to Tekken or the various Street Fighter arcade ports, Dynasty Warriors was not a top-tier fighting game for the console. It had its place in time and can be thanked for bringing fans the hack and slash series that started with Dynasty Warriors 2 on the PS2, but itâ€™s not much of a must-play PS1 game now.

Final Fantasy Chronicles

A Bad Way To Play Two Great RPGS

  • Publisher: Square Electronic Arts
  • Released: July 2, 2001 (NA)

Final Fantasy Chronicles was a collection of two great SNES RPGs: Final Fantasy 4 and Chrono Trigger . It was the cheapest way to buy and play both, as the SNES cartridges at this point were either hard to find or very expensive. It was a port of convenience, if anything, and there were some cool new features like the CG cutscenes in Final Fantasy 4 or the anime cutscenes in Chrono Trigger . Thatâ€™s where the praises stop because these are some of the worst ways to play these classics, as the load times were infamously bad, and they didnâ€™t exactly age well. Final Fantasy 4 has tons of great ports to play now, and Chrono Trigger has fewer, but they are better options than this collection.
